case_id: C. Mangesh & Ors v. State of Karnataka (2010) 7 SCC 667
facts: Marriage between C. Mangesh (Appellant No. 1/Accused No. 1 - A-1) and deceased Manjula on 15.05.1996.
Alleged demand of Rs. 10,000 cash and 50 grams gold as dowry at the time of marriage.
Rs. 5,000 cash and 25 grams gold were allegedly given, with a promise to pay the balance later.
Prosecution alleged continuous harassment and torture of Manjula by A-1 (husband), A-2 (father-in-law T. Venkatappa), and A-3 (brother-in-law T. Narayanappa) for the remaining dowry.
Manjula was allegedly sent back to her parental home after about 6 months due to non-payment.
A panchayat was held, and Manjula was taken back to the matrimonial home.
On 11.07.1997 (within 1 year and 2 months of marriage), Manjula was found dead by hanging in her matrimonial home in Madhugiri Taluk, Tumkur District.
FIR registered based on the complaint by PW-1 (father of the deceased).
Post-mortem examination conducted by Dr. Hanumantharaya (PW-12) opined death due to asphyxia as a result of hanging.
Charge-sheet filed against A-1, A-2, and A-3 under Sections 498-A, 304-B, 302 read with Section 34 IPC, and Sections 3 & 4 of the Dowry Prohibition Act, 1961.

Trial Court (Sessions Judge, Tumkur) acquitted all accused of all charges by judgment dated 31.01.2000, citing discrepancies in witness testimonies (PW-1, PW-2, PW-3) and lack of reliable evidence for dowry demand/cruelty 'soon before death'.
State of Karnataka appealed to the High Court of Karnataka.

High Court, by judgment dated 16.12.2005, reversed the acquittal in part: Convicted A-1, A-2, and A-3 under Section 304-B read with Section 34 IPC (7 years RI) and Section 498-A read with Section 34 IPC (3 years RI and fine of Rs. 2000 each). Acquittal under Section 302/34 IPC and Dowry Prohibition Act sections was confirmed.

High Court found the trial court's acquittal regarding Sections 304-B and 498-A to be perverse, relying on testimonies of PW-1 (father), PW-2 (mother), PW-3 (brother) and invoking the presumption under Section 113-B of the Indian Evidence Act.
The present appeal before the Supreme Court was filed by the convicted accused (A-1, A-2, A-3) against the High Court's judgment.
ipc_sections: Section 498A (Cruelty by Husband or Relatives - convicted by HC)
Section 3 & 4, Dowry Prohibition Act, 1961 (Charged, acquitted by HC)

prosecution_arguments.argument: The High Court correctly reversed the perverse acquittal by the Trial Court, as the Trial Court ignored credible evidence establishing dowry demand and cruelty.
precedents: Chandrappa v. State of Karnataka, (2007) 4 SCC 415 (Principles for appeal against acquittal)
State of U.P. v. Ramesh Prasad Misra, (1996) 10 SCC 360 (Appellate court's power to re-appreciate evidence in appeal against acquittal)
Dhananjay Chatterjee alias Dhana v. State of W.B., (1994) 2 SCC 220 (Interference with acquittal justified when trial court findings are unreasonable or distorted)
elements: Credibility of PW-1, PW-2, PW-3 testimonies
Correct application of appellate powers by High Court

counter_arguments.loophole: High Court re-appreciated evidence simply because a different view was possible, without demonstrating clear perversity or unreasonableness in the Trial Court's assessment.
supporting_precedents: Basappa v. State of Karnataka, (2014) 5 SCC 154 (High threshold for reversing acquittal)
Ramesh Babulal Doshi v. State of Gujarat, (1996) 9 SCC 225 (Acquittal reversal requires glaring errors/misreading of evidence)

prosecution_arguments.argument: All ingredients of Section 304-B IPC were proven: unnatural death within 7 years of marriage, preceded by dowry-related cruelty/harassment.
precedents: Kamesh Panjiyar v. State of Bihar, (2005) 2 SCC 388 (Definition and scope of 'dowry demand' and 'cruelty' under 304B/498A)
State of Punjab v. Iqbal Singh, (1991) 3 SCC 1 (Presumption under Section 113B Evidence Act arises once foundational facts of 304B are shown)
Pawan Kumar v. State of Haryana, (1998) 3 SCC 309 (Link between dowry demand, cruelty, and death)
elements: Death otherwise than under normal circumstances (hanging)
Death within 7 years of marriage (1 year 2 months)

counter_arguments.loophole: The prosecution failed to establish a proximate and live link between the alleged harassment and the death; 'soon before death' element not conclusively proven.
supporting_precedents: Kaliaperumal v. State of T.N., (2004) 9 SCC 157 (Meaning of 'soon before death' requires proximity)
Rajinder Singh v. State of Punjab, (2015) 6 SCC 477 (Mere death within 7 years and past harassment insufficient; need link)

prosecution_arguments.argument: Testimonies of close relatives (PW-1, PW-2, PW-3) regarding dowry demand and cruelty are credible and sufficient for conviction under Sections 304-B and 498-A.
precedents: State of Punjab v. Gurmit Singh, (1996) 2 SCC 384 (Testimony of victim/relatives in sexual/family offenses carries weight)
Trimukh Maroti Kirkan v. State of Maharashtra, (2006) 10 SCC 681 (Dowry deaths often occur within privacy of home; relative testimony crucial)
Gura Singh v. State of Rajasthan, (2001) 2 SCC 205 (Minor discrepancies in relative testimonies do not negate core case)
elements: Proof of harassment/cruelty linked to demand

counter_arguments.loophole: Witnesses are close relatives and thus 'interested'; their testimonies lacked independent corroboration and contained contradictions noted by the Trial Court.
supporting_precedents: Surinder Kumar v. State of Haryana, (2011) 10 SCC 173 (Caution needed with interested witnesses; corroboration desirable)
M. Narsinga Rao v. State of A.P., (2001) 1 SCC 691 (Scrutiny of interested witness testimony required)

prosecution_arguments.argument: The presumption under Section 113-B of the Indian Evidence Act was correctly invoked by the High Court, shifting the burden onto the accused to disprove culpability for dowry death.
precedents: Shamnsaheb M. Multtani v. State of Karnataka, (2001) 2 SCC 577 (Conditions for invoking Section 113B presumption)
Pathan Hussain Basha v. State of A.P., (2012) 8 SCC 594 (Nature of Section 113B presumption - mandatory once prerequisites met)
Sher Singh @ Partapa v. State of Haryana, (2015) 3 SCC 724 (Rebuttal of presumption requires proof beyond reasonable doubt by accused)
elements: Establishment of foundational facts for Sec 304-B

counter_arguments.loophole: The prosecution failed to establish the foundational fact of cruelty 'soon before death' beyond reasonable doubt, thus the presumption under Section 113-B could not be legally invoked.
supporting_precedents: Baijnath v. State of M.P., (2017) 1 SCC 101 (Prosecution must prove foundational facts beyond reasonable doubt before presumption applies)
Baljeet Singh v. State of Haryana, (2004) 3 SCC 122 (If basic ingredients not proven, presumption cannot be drawn)

defense_arguments.argument: The High Court erred in reversing the well-reasoned acquittal by the Trial Court, exceeding its jurisdiction under CrPC governing appeals against acquittal.
edge_cases: Scope of appellate review in acquittal appeals
precedents: Sheo Swarup v. King Emperor, AIR 1934 PC 227 (Principles for appeal against acquittal)
Muralidhar @ Gidda v. State of Karnataka, (2014) 5 SCC 730 (Reversal only if trial court view is impossible or perverse)
Ghurey Lal v. State of U.P., (2008) 10 SCC 450 (Reiterating stringent standards for overturning acquittal)

defense_arguments.argument: The crucial element of 'soon before death' for Section 304-B was not established. General allegations of past harassment are insufficient.
edge_cases: Requirement of a live link between cruelty and death
precedents: Tarsem Singh v. State of Punjab, (2008) 16 SCC 155 ('Soon before' implies proximate link, not remote instances)
Surinder Singh v. State of Haryana, (2014) 4 SCC 129 (Need for cogent evidence of cruelty proximate to death)
Bansi Lal v. State of Haryana, (2011) 11 SCC 359 (Vague allegations insufficient for 'soon before death')

defense_arguments.argument: Evidence against A-2 (father-in-law) and A-3 (brother-in-law) was based on general and omnibus allegations, insufficient to prove their specific involvement in cruelty or dowry demand under Sections 498-A or 304-B.
edge_cases: Requirement of specific allegations against each accused relative
precedents: Kans Raj v. State of Punjab, (2000) 5 SCC 207 (Need for specific evidence against each relative)
Preeti Gupta v. State of Jharkhand, (2010) 7 SCC 667 (Tendency to implicate all family members; need for caution)
Geeta Mehrotra v. State of U.P., (2012) 10 SCC 741 (Quashing of charges based on vague allegations against distant relatives)

defense_arguments.argument: The testimonies of PW-1, PW-2, and PW-3 (father, mother, brother) were contradictory, improved, and lacked independent corroboration, making them unreliable.
edge_cases: Impact of contradictions and improvements on witness credibility
precedents: Harijan Bhala Teja v. State of Gujarat, (2016) 12 SCC 665 (Contradictions affecting core of case warrant acquittal)
Dalip Singh v. State of Punjab, AIR 1953 SC 364 (Principles for evaluating related/interested witnesses)
Vadivelu Thevar v. State of Madras, AIR 1957 SC 614 (Classification of witnesses - wholly reliable, wholly unreliable, neither wholly reliable nor wholly unreliable)

judgment.outcome: Appeal allowed. The judgment of the High Court convicting the appellants (A-1, A-2, A-3) under Sections 304-B/34 and 498-A/34 IPC was set aside. The judgment of the Trial Court acquitting all appellants was restored.
reasoning: The Supreme Court found that the High Court was not justified in reversing the Trial Court's acquittal.
The Trial Court had identified significant contradictions and improvements in the testimonies of key prosecution witnesses (PW-1, PW-2, PW-3) regarding the dowry demand and harassment.
There was no independent witness corroborating the allegations of cruelty or dowry demand.

The crucial ingredient of Section 304-B, that the cruelty or harassment occurred 'soon before death', was not convincingly established by the prosecution. The allegations were mostly general in nature, relating to incidents long before the death.
The panchayat meeting mentioned occurred several months prior to the incident, weakening the proximity required for 'soon before death'.
Given the lack of reliable evidence proving cruelty 'soon before death' beyond reasonable doubt, the presumption under Section 113-B of the Evidence Act could not be invoked.

The Trial Court's view based on the evidence on record was a possible and plausible view. The High Court erred in substituting its own view without demonstrating that the Trial Court's findings were perverse or patently erroneous.
The allegations against the father-in-law (A-2) and brother-in-law (A-3) were particularly vague and lacked specific details of their involvement.
For Section 498-A conviction also, the evidence regarding cruelty was found unreliable due to contradictions and lack of corroboration.
